Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Estimated GHG emission reductions:
The project activity generated renewable electricity without any GHG emissions, which
displaced part of the electricity otherwise supplied by grid connected fossil fuel fired power
plants. Thus, GHG emission reductions can be achieved. The expected CO emission 2
reduction from the proposed project is 64,206 tCO e annually and 642,060 tCO2e in total 2
over the first 10 years crediting period.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope : 01 - Energy industries (renewable / non-renewable sources)
Project Type : I - Renewable Energy Projects
Project Category : Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources
ACM0002- Version 19.0
1.3 Project Eligibility
According to VCS Standard, version 4.0, the scope of the VCS Program includes:
1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
2) Ozone-depleting substances.
3) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under the VCS Program
through the methodology approval process.
4) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program, unless explicitly excluded under the terms of VERRA approval.
5) Jurisdictional REDD+ programs and nested REDD+ projects as set out in the VCS
Program document Jurisdictional and Nested REDD+ (JNR) Requirements.
The project activity generated renewable electricity without any GHG emissions, which
displaced part of the electricity otherwise been supplied by grid connected fossil fuel fired
power plants generating mainly CO emission. Thus, GHG emission reductions can be 2
achieved. The project is eligible under the scope (the six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases)
of the VCS Program.
1.4 Project Design
The project activity involves the single installation and operation of Srepok 1 solar power
plant with capacity of 50 MW.
Eligibility Criteria
The proposed project is not a group project activity. Thus, this section is not applicable.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed project activity involves the installation of Wind Power Projects. The total installed
capacity of the project is 60 MW; which involves operation of 30 Wind Turbine Generators
(WTGs) with capacity of 2 MW each located at Maharashtra state in India. The project is
promoted by CLP Wind Farms (India) Private Limited.
The Project activity is a new facility (Greenfield) and the purpose of the project activity is to
generate energy electricity by the utilization of wind velocity power and further selling the
generated energy to the NEWNE Grid. In this process there is no consumption of any fossil fuel
and hence the project does not lead to any greenhouse gas emissions. Thus, electricity would be
generated through sustainable means without causing any negative impact on the environment.
The estimated annual average GHG emission reductions from the project activity will be 118,364
tonnes of CO2 and total GHG emission reductions for the chosen 10 year crediting period will be
1,183,640 tonnes of CO2.
In the Pre- project scenario the entire electricity, delivered to the grid by the project activity, would
have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the
addition of new generation sources.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project activity falls under the following Sectoral scope and Project Type:
Sectoral Scope : 01 - Energy industries (renewable / non renewable sources)
Project Type : I - Renewable Energy Projects
Methodology:
ACM0002: Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources --- Version 16.0

1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
The Project is owned by CLP Wind Farms (India) Private Limited, hence it possess right of use of
ER credits. The Ownership is demonstrated through the following documents.

by the PP
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
Net GHG emission reductions or removals generated by the Project will not be used for
compliance with an emissions trading program or to meet binding limits on GHG emissions in any
Emission Trading program or other binding limits.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Project has no intend to generate any other form of GHG-related environmental credit for
GHG emission reductions or removals claimed under the VCS Program.
1.12.4 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The Project has not participated in any other GHG programs.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Project is not rejected by other GHG programs.

CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
3 CLIMATE
3.1 Application of Methodology
3.1.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
This is an AFOLU A/R project that aims to recover degraded lands, which are expected to remain
degraded or to continue to degrade in the absence of the project. The project is a grouped project.
Methodology applied:
AR-ACM0003 (United Nations, 2020)17. A/R Large-scale Consolidated Methodology. Afforestation and
reforestation of lands except for wetlands. Version 2.0. Sectoral scope(s): 14.
Tools applied (United Nations, 2020)18:
• “Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality in A/R CDM
project activities” Version 01.
• “Estimation of non-CO2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions resulting from burning of biomass
attributable to an A/R CDM project activity” Version 04.0.0.
• “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs in A/R CDM
project activities” Version 04.2.
• “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks in dead wood and litter in A/R CDM
project activities” Version 03.1.
• “Tool for estimation of change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R
CDM project activities” Version 01.1.0.
• “Estimation of the increase in GHG emissions attributable to the displacement of pre-project
agricultural activities in A/R CDM project activity” Version 02.0.
Other A/R CDM tools used in this project are:
• “Calculation of the number of sample plots for measurements within A/R CDM project activities”
Version 2.1.0.
3.1.2 Applicability of Methodology
Demonstrate and justify how the project activity(s) meets each of the applicability conditions of the
methodology(s), and tools (where applicable) applied by the project. Address each applicability condition
separately.

Question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

Context: 

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Guizhou Qingshuihe Gelibridge Hydropower Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is
to utilize the hydro resource for renewable electricity generation through the construction of
a 150MW (2*75MW) hydropower plant located at Maoyun village in Kaiyang county of
Guizhou province, the People’s Republic of China. The owner of the project is Guizhou
Wujiang Qingshuihe Hydropower Development Co., Ltd. The construction of the hydropower
plant started in June of 2007. Partial operation of the project (1 of 2 turbines) commenced
on 06/02/2010 and full operation (2 of 2 turbines) started on 12/03/2010. The electricity
generated by the project is 508GWh annually, of which 497.3 GWh is supplied to the South
China Power Grid via the local Guizhou Power Grid.
The project is a grid-connected renewable energy project by replacing grid electricity, which
otherwise would have been produced mainly by fossil fuel fired power plants. The scenario
existing prior to the start of implementation of the project activity is the provision of equivalent
quantity of electricity generated mostly by fossil fuel fired power plants (coal) connected to
the South China Power Grid. The baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing
prior to the start of implementation of the project activity. The estimated annual GHG
emission reductions of the project are 179,625tCO e and the total GHG emission reductions 2
are 1,796,250tCO e during the second crediting period from 06/02/2020 to 05/02/2030. 2
The project was registered with the VCS registry with the registration number 656. VCS
VCUs from 06/02/2010 to 03/10/2010 were issued already.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Category: 1 – Energy industries (renewable / non-renewable sources)
Project Activity: Grid-connected renewable power generation from a hydropower plant with
a reservoir.
The project is not a grouped project, which is defined by the VCS standard v4.1 as a number
of projects and their related methodologies included in a single VCS PD at the time of the
validation. The project is a single project at a single location.
1.3 Project Eligibility
• The project does not generate GHG emissions primarily for the purpose of their
subsequent reduction, removal or destruction;
• The project does not have created another form of environmental credit.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The purpose of the grouped project activity is to install and operate run-off river pico/micro/small-
hydropower plants in Madagascar, with a focus on rural areas. The grouped project activity is part of
Tany Meva’s contribution to the implementation of the National Rural Electrification Program and
contributes to local development.
The installation of a first batch of 4 micro/small-hydroelectricity run-off river plants, between 60 and 200
kW each, in the Analamanga and Amoron’Imania regions will generate an average of 700 MWh per year.
They will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 1,070 tCO /yr, a result of the substitution of fossil-fuel 2
based power generation by clean and renewable energy. The technology to be employed is hydraulic &
electromechanical equipment including micro-hydroelectricity turbines and generators, as well as
transformers feeding in to medium and low tension grids. The project activity instances will benefit over
77,000 individuals (1,580 households, 38 schools, farmers, public services and at least 8 rural
entrepreneurs).
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The type of the project is Abatement and the field is Energy industries (renewable sources). Sectoral
scope 1. The project is a VCS Grouped (multiple) project.

The project is located in the south of Qiannan Prefecture, Guizhou Province, China, covering
Duyun City, Dushan County, Pingtang County and Sandu County. The geographical coordinates of
the project are between 107°07' E-107°46' E and 25°51' N-26°26' N.

are the areas of the project. Please refer to Section 3.3 for the boundaries of the project zone is

2 VCS Methodology:
2.1 Title and reference of the VCS methodology applied to the project activity and
explanation of methodology choices:
Methodology applied: UNFCCC Clean Development Mechanism approved small
scale methodology AMS-I.D Ver 13.
The project activity is
a) installation and operation of four renewable energy generation units that use wind
energy to generate electricity that is supplied to the electricity distribution system,
i.e. the NEWNE Grid,
b) the total rated generation capacity of the project activity is 5.0 MW that is less
than 15MW as stipulated by the methodology AMS-I.D Ver 13,
c) the generating units are also new installations and not capacity addition in an
existing renewable energy generation facility of the project proponent,
d) there is no combined heat and power (co-generation) generation involved in the
project activity.
Hence, application of approved small-scale methodology AMS-I.D Ver 13 is justified
for the project activity..
2.2 Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the
project activity:
The project activity comprises of renewable energy generation utilising wind energy.
The electricity generated is supplied to the electricity distribution system, i.e. the
NEWNE Grid. The total rated generation capacity of the project activity is 5 MW that
is less than 15 MW as stipulated by the methodology AMS-I.D Ver 13. The
generating unit is also a new installation and not capacity addition in an existing
renewable energy generation facility of the project proponent. Hence, application of
approved small-scale methodology AMS-I.D Ver 13 is justified for the project
activity.

SECTION D. Environmental impacts:
>>
D.1. If required by the host Party, documentation on the analysis of the environmental
impacts of the project activity:
>>
The project does not exceed the threshold limits of the host party above which environmental
impact analysis should be conducted. The project activity does not fall under the purview of
Environmental Impact Assessment notification of the Ministry of Environment and Forests
(MoEF) -Government of India (Reference: Environment Impact Assessment Notification dated
27/01/1994 and its subsequent amendments).
The environmental impact of the project activity is negligible as follows:
• The project does not consume any fossil fuels in its operation. Electricity imported by the
project equipment is adjusted against the electricity exported. Therefore does not have any
project GHG emissions.
• The project equipment is not transferred form any other project activity and therefore does
not have any leakage GHG emissions.
• The project activity does not generate any emissions to the air.
• The project activity does not generate solid waste apart from material used or removed
during maintenance for repairs, cleaning, and/or lubrication.
• The project activity does not generate any discharge of effluents.

by the host Party

in the project activity, prospective benefits of GHG reduction and contribution to sustainable
development were discussed at the meeting and the stakeholders were given a presentation in
English and in the regional language (Kannada). The equipment and technology used in the
project activity, prospective benefits of GHG reduction and contribution to sustainable
development were described. Stakeholders were invited to give their feedback on the project
during the open discussion held at the meeting. All stakeholder consultation documents have been
submitted to the DOE at the time of Validation.

1.13 Conditions Before Project Initiation
Before the start of the project, the economic development of the project area was poor, and the
local farmers lacked advanced irrigation technologies such as intermittent flood irrigation. The
intermittent irrigation method requires that in the process of rice cultivation, irrigation and
drainage can be controlled by ditches and valves according to the growing needs of rice. The low
economic level leads to the low income of farmers, which means that farmers do not have the
additional financial capacity to afford the construction of cement ditches that can implement
controlled irrigation and drainage. Therefore, the project has not yet been implemented to
generate greenhouse gas emissions for subsequent reduction, removal, or destruction.
Since the conditions existing before the project initiation are the same as the baseline scenario,
please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) to see the detailed information.
• Ecosystem type: The major ecosystem type of Liupanshui City is forest. Liupanshui City
has a forest area of 609,333 ha, with a forest coverage rate of 61.51%.
• Current and historical land use: The area of Liupanshui City to the agricultural land area
is 23,430 ha. The rapid economic development of Liupanshui City has not resulted in
the occupation or destruction of cultivated land. At present, the land use is still
dominated by agricultural land, supplemented by construction land and unused land.

{'project_name': 'Zangke Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice cultivation is conducted in Liupanshui City, Guizhou Province, China, with a total acreage of 19,067 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline 
scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase, and less methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth, farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%. Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 3.09 tCO2e/ha.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 412,951 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 58,993 tCO2e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standards of local farmers and provide more job opportunities.', 'project_state_province': 'Guizhou Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 26.5, 'project_longitude': 105.18}

According to the National Ecosystem Map of Peru elaborated by the Ministry of Environment

Yunga High-montane Forest (Pluvial)
High montane forest ecosystem (between 2,500 and 3,600-3,800 m.a.s.l.) with an extremely
rough physiography. Closed canopy forest, with up to three distinguishable strata. The canopy
or tree top height reaches 10-15 meters, with some 20-meter emerging trees.
Flooded Alluvial Forest
Alluvial landscape ecosystem in the Amazon plain on flat lands (0-5%) that suffer periodic
flooding due to the usual water level rise (5 to 8 meters high). The soils are subject to
temporary or almost permanent flooding; the forest with sparse or open undergrowth may
have 3 or 4 strata with a canopy or tree top height that reaches 20 to 25 meters, and emerging
individuals up to 30 meters high.
Yunga Basimontane Forest
Low montane non-cloudy ecosystem located on the eastern slopes of the Andes (between 600
to 800 and 1,500 to 1,800 m.a.s.l.), with slopes that can exceed 100%. Closed canopy forest,
with three distinguishable strata. The canopy or tree top height reaches at least 25 meters,
with some 35-meter emerging trees.
High Hill Forest
Amazon ecosystem located on moderately to heavily gully-divided non-flooded lands, with
relative altitudes from 80 to 300 meters, steep (60%) and very steep (70-80%) slopes, that
make them highly susceptible to water erosion. The undergrowth is dense; the forest may have
3 or 4 strata with a canopy or tree top height that reaches 25 meters, and 30- to 35-meter-
high emerging individuals.
Low Hill Forest
Amazon ecosystem located on gully-divided non-flooded lands, with hills of relative heights
from 20 to 80 meters, moderately steep (25-30%) and steep (up to 50%) slopes, that make
them highly susceptible to water erosion. The undergrowth is dense; the forest may have 3 or
4 strata with a canopy or tree top height that reaches 25 to 30 meters, and 35-meter or more
emerging individuals.
Non-floodable Terrace Forest
Solid ground ecosystem, topography generally flat or with slight undulations up to 20 meters
high as you move away from the river. The undergrowth is dense; the forest may have 3 or 4

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project is to change from continuously flooded water regimes to intermittently flooded water
regimes during rice cultivation in Rongchang District, Chongqing City, China, with a total acreage
of 18,847 ha of single-cropping rice. A total of 8,395 households (36,602 farmers) were involved
in the project. Without the project, local villagers would not have access to intermittently flooded
technology and intact facilities to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional
continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was
cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic
decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of
methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to water
efficiency, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded
method.
The implementation activities of the project include promoting intermittently flooded technology,
technical training for the farmers, facility repair and replacement, etc. According to the needs of
rice growth, farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only
saves water resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under
anaerobic conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to
the rice paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice
paddies in the rainy season.
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by 416,388 tCO e in the first seven-year period, 2
with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,484 tCO e. The project aims to reduce 2
GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living standards
for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice
cultivation is conducted in Liupanshui City, Guizhou Province, China, with a total acreage of
19,067 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the project, which provides ditches to conduct
intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued,
so the scenario that rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline
scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount
of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more
beneficial to water conservation, production increase, and less methane emission reduction than
the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 3.09
tCO e/ha. 2
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
412,951 tCO e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 2
58,993 tCO e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase the rice 2
productivity resulting in higher living standards of local farmers and provide more job
opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)”
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

members and stakeholders who wi sh to gain information about the Pr oject and/or submit comments or 
grievances. The primary communication method to stakeholders and communities is through the 
Project Partner’s existing channels of communication to the respective communities in their area. 
Meetings were mainly announced thr ough phone calls or by informing the leader of a specific 
community group (women’s groups, youth groups, etc.) in a timely fashion, who in turn would 
communicate the information to the members of that group.

documentation. Community members are encouraged to visit these headquarters where they have full 
access to any such material. The Project Office constructed seven signboards  that were installed at 
strateg ic points around the Project Zone for posting of project information. The SBIA community 
meetings took place August 15 -17 and August 23 -25, 2017 in the MoE offices, Koh Kong province. In 
addition, community FPIC meetings have occurred  over 3 rounds . Round one community FPIC 
meetings took place from August to October 2017  with 24 meetings being  held. During that period, a 
half day meeting was held in each targeted village. Significant time was given between the initial

The crediting period of this project will be using a 7-year, twice renewable crediting period, for a
combined total project crediting 21 years from 08-April-2020 to 07-April-2041, and the first 7-
year period is from 08-April-2020 to 07-April-2027. Also, the project lifetime3 is 30 years from

the project lifetime is 30 years. The project's lifetime starts from the date the ditches are completed, so the start date of the
project lifetime is earlier than the project's start date.
4 Section 3.8 of the VCS Standard, v4.2 states that “The project crediting period is the time for which GHG emission reductions
or removals generated by the project are eligible for issuance as VCUs.” According to the Methodology of Methane emission
reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice cultivation, the time when the project produces emission
reductions is the start time of land preparation. And the land preparation means the start of a rice season. The main activity
of this project is emission reduction due to adjusted water regime during rice cultivation, which means emission reduction for
each year only occurred thought the rice-growing season. Therefore, although the crediting period in 2020 does not start
from 1st January, it has already included the whole rice-growing season in a year.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03
CDM – Executive Board

SECTION A. General description of small-scale project activity
A.1 Title of the small-scale project activity:
Taohua 9MW Hydro Power Project in Guizhou Province, China
The version 4.0 PDD was completed on 18/09/2007
A.2. Description of the small-scale project activity:
Taohua Hydro Power Project in Guizhou Province of China is a run-of-river hydro power plant sited in
Wangsi Town, Duyun City in Guizhou Province with the installed capacity 9MW.The proposed project
was developed by the Water Resource Bureau of Qiannan district and started to construct in 1996, but the
proposed project was shut down in 1998 because of short fund. In 2004 the project owner purchased this
project and continued to develop this project according to the stipulation of CDM.
The hinge of the power project includes the arch dam with the height of 40.2m, the hydropower tunnels
with the length of 206m and the power plant. There are 2 generators with the type of SF3000-22/3250 and
1 generator with the type of SF3000-20/3250, and 2 turbines with the type of HLD74-LJ-150 and 1
turbine with type of HLF13-LJ-140.The electricity generated by the proposed project will be connected to
Guizhou Province Power Grid, finally to China Southern Power Grid. The annual electricity generation is
37,800MWh, and the annual feed-in electricity to the grid is 36,670MWh[1]. Electricity generated by the
proposed project will displace part of the electricity generated by China Southern Power Grid which is
dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants, and thus greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions could be
achieved. The estimated annual GHG emission reductions of Taohua project are 29,516 tCO e[2]. 2
As a renewable hydro power project, the proposed project will produce positive environmental and
economic benefits and contribute to the local sustainable development through following aspects:
(cid:122) To be consistent with China’s national energy policy and the Western Development Strategy,
will alleviate power shortage in the local areas, will improve the local poor condition and
advance the standard of living of local people.
(cid:122) To displace part of the electricity from coal-fired power plants, and thus will avoid
environmental pollution caused by coal burning.
(cid:122) To create new job opportunities for the local people. In the construction period, the rural
labour force can be arranged.11 long-term job opportunities will be provided in the operation
period[3].
(cid:122) After the operation of the proposed project, the local people can make good use of electricity
instead of biomass, especially firewood, which can reduce the destroying to local vegetation and
protect the environment.

Reformer Commission(NDRC) and revised by DOE.
3 Refer to the actual personnel arrangement of Taohua Hydro Power Project.
